a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "(crossproduct (vector [1, 0, 0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0, 1, 0]) (vector [1, 0, 0])) +
               crossproduct (vector [0, 1, 0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0, 0, 1]) (vector [0, 1, 0])) +
               crossproduct (vector [0, 0, 1]) (crossproduct (v - vector [1, 0, 0]) (vector [0, 0, 1]))) = vector [0, 0, 0]"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "(crossproduct (vector [1, 0, 0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0, 1, 0]) (vector [1, 0, 0])) +
               crossproduct (vector [0, 1, 0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0, 0, 1]) (vector [0, 1, 0])) +
               crossproduct (vector [0, 0, 1]) (crossproduct (v - vector [1, 0, 0]) (vector [0, 0, 1]))) = vector [0, 0, 0]"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the vector $v$ in $\mathbb{R}^3$ such that the cross product of the vector $[1, 0, 0]$ with the cross product of $v - [0, 1, 0]$ and $[1, 0, 0]$, plus the cross product of the vector $[0, 1, 0]$ with the cross product of $v - [0, 0, 1]$ and $[0, 1, 0]$, plus the cross product of the vector $[0, 0, 1]$ with the cross product of $v - [1, 0, 0]$ and $[0, 0, 1]$, is equal to the zero vector $[0, 0, 0]$. The final answer is $v = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j k v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1, 0, 0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0, 1, 0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h3 : "cross i (cross (v - j) i) + cross j (cross (v - k) j) + cross k (cross (v - i) k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes i j k v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1, 0, 0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0, 1, 0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h3 : "cross i (cross (v - j) i) + cross j (cross (v - k) j) + cross k (cross (v - i) k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the vectors i = [1, 0, 0], j = [0, 1, 0], k = [0, 0, 1], find the vector v such that the sum of the cross product of i with the cross product of (v - j) and i, the cross product of j with the cross product of (v - k) and j, and the cross product of k with the cross product of (v - i) and k equals to the zero vector. The final answer is v = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2].

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v i j k :: real^3
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1,0,0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0,1,0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0,0,1]"
and h3 : "cross i ((v - j) cross i) + cross j ((v - k) cross j) + cross k ((v - i) cross k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v i j k :: real^3
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1,0,0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0,1,0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0,0,1]"
and h3 : "cross i ((v - j) cross i) + cross j ((v - k) cross j) + cross k ((v - i) cross k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given three vectors $i = [1,0,0]$, $j = [0,1,0]$, and $k = [0,0,1]$, find a vector $v$ such that the sum of the cross products of $i$ with the cross product of $v$ and $j$, $j$ with the cross product of $v$ and $k$, and $k$ with the cross product of $v$ and $i$, is a zero vector. The final answer is $v = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "cross (vector [1,0,0]) (cross (v - vector [0,1,0]) (vector [1,0,0])) + cross (vector [0,1,0]) (cross (v - vector [0,0,1]) (vector [0,1,0])) + cross (vector [0,0,1]) (cross (v - vector [1,0,0]) (vector [0,0,1])) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "cross (vector [1,0,0]) (cross (v - vector [0,1,0]) (vector [1,0,0])) + cross (vector [0,1,0]) (cross (v - vector [0,0,1]) (vector [0,1,0])) + cross (vector [0,0,1]) (cross (v - vector [1,0,0]) (vector [0,0,1])) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find a vector $v$ in three-dimensional space such that the cross product of vector $[1,0,0]$ and the cross product of $v - [0,1,0]$ and $[1,0,0]$, plus the cross product of $[0,1,0]$ and the cross product of $v - [0,0,1]$ and $[0,1,0]$, plus the cross product of $[0,0,1]$ and the cross product of $v - [1,0,0]$ and $[0,0,1]$ is the zero vector. The final answer is $v = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "crossproduct (vector [1,0,0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0,1,0]) (vector [1,0,0])) 
+ crossproduct (vector [0,1,0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0,0,1]) (vector [0,1,0])) 
+ crossproduct (vector [0,0,1]) (crossproduct (v - vector [1,0,0]) (vector [0,0,1])) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "crossproduct (vector [1,0,0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0,1,0]) (vector [1,0,0])) 
+ crossproduct (vector [0,1,0]) (crossproduct (v - vector [0,0,1]) (vector [0,1,0])) 
+ crossproduct (vector [0,0,1]) (crossproduct (v - vector [1,0,0]) (vector [0,0,1])) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a vector v in three-dimensional space, if the cross product of the vector from (1,0,0) to v and (1,0,0) added to the cross product of the vector from (0,1,0) to v and (0,1,0), and further added to the cross product of the vector from (0,0,1) to v and (0,0,1) equals the zero vector, then v is the vector (1/2, 1/2, 1/2).

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "(crossproduct (unit_vec 1) (crossproduct (v - unit_vec 2) (unit_vec 1))) + (crossproduct (unit_vec 2) (crossproduct (v - unit_vec 3) (unit_vec 2))) + (crossproduct (unit_vec 3) (crossproduct (v - unit_vec 1) (unit_vec 3))) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}

 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "(crossproduct (unit_vec 1) (crossproduct (v - unit_vec 2) (unit_vec 1))) + (crossproduct (unit_vec 2) (crossproduct (v - unit_vec 3) (unit_vec 2))) + (crossproduct (unit_vec 3) (crossproduct (v - unit_vec 1) (unit_vec 3))) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the three-dimensional vector v that satisfies the following condition: the sum of the cross products of the unit vector in the first direction with the cross product of v minus the unit vector in the second direction with the unit vector in the first direction, the unit vector in the second direction with the cross product of v minus the unit vector in the third direction with the unit vector in the second direction, and the unit vector in the third direction with the cross product of v minus the unit vector in the first direction with the unit vector in the third direction, all sum to zero. The final answer is the vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2].

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j k v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1,0,0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0,1,0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0,0,1]"
and h3 : "i cross ((v - j) cross i) + j cross ((v - k) cross j) + k cross ((v - i) cross k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes i j k v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1,0,0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0,1,0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0,0,1]"
and h3 : "i cross ((v - j) cross i) + j cross ((v - k) cross j) + k cross ((v - i) cross k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given three unit vectors i = [1,0,0], j = [0,1,0], and k = [0,0,1], find a vector v such that the sum of the cross products of i with the cross product of v and j, j with the cross product of v and k, and k with the cross product of v and i equals to zero. The final answer is v = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2].

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^3" and i j k :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i \<times> ((v - j) \<times> i) + j \<times> ((v - k) \<times> j) + k \<times> ((v - i) \<times> k) = 0"
shows  "v = (1/2, 1/2, 1/2)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^3" and i j k :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i \<times> ((v - j) \<times> i) + j \<times> ((v - k) \<times> j) + k \<times> ((v - i) \<times> k) = 0"
shows  "v = (1/2, 1/2, 1/2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Given three vectors $i$, $j$, and $k$, and a fourth vector $v$, if the following equation holds:

$i \times ((v - j) \times i) + j \times ((v - k) \times j) + k \times ((v - i) \times k) = 0$

Find the vector $v$. The final answer is $(1/2, 1/2, 1/2)$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j k v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1,0,0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0,1,0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0,0,1]"
and h3 : "cross i (cross (v - j) i) + cross j (cross (v - k) j) + cross k (cross (v - i) k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes i j k v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "i = vector [1,0,0]"
and h1 : "j = vector [0,1,0]"
and h2 : "k = vector [0,0,1]"
and h3 : "cross i (cross (v - j) i) + cross j (cross (v - k) j) + cross k (cross (v - i) k) = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given three vectors i, j, and k, defined as i = [1, 0, 0], j = [0, 1, 0], and k = [0, 0, 1], find a vector v such that the sum of the cross products of i with the difference of v and j, j with the difference of v and k, and k with the difference of v and i, is zero. The final answer is v = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2].

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "(crossproduct (vector [1,0,0]) (crossproduct (v - (vector [0,1,0])) (vector [1,0,0]))) + 
(crossproduct (vector [0,1,0]) (crossproduct (v - (vector [0,0,1])) (vector [0,1,0]))) + 
(crossproduct (vector [0,0,1]) (crossproduct (v - (vector [1,0,0])) (vector [0,0,1]))) = vector [0,0,0]"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] = \mathbf{0}.\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 In general, the vector triple product states that for any vectors $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c},$ \[\mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \mathbf{b} - (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \mathbf{c}.\]Then
 \begin{align} \mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] &=(\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{i}) (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) - (\mathbf{i} \cdot (\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j})) \mathbf{i} \\ &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{j}) \mathbf{i} \\
 &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j} - (\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i}. \end{align}Similarly, \begin{align} \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k} - (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j}, \\
 \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] &= \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}, \end{align}so \begin{align} &\mathbf{i} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{j}) \times \mathbf{i}] + \mathbf{j} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{k}) \times \mathbf{j}] + \mathbf{k} \times [(\mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i}) \times \mathbf{k}] \\
 &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - ((\mathbf{i} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{i} + (\mathbf{j} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{j} + (\mathbf{k} \cdot \mathbf{v}) \mathbf{k}) \\ &= 3 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k} - \mathbf{v} \\
 &= 2 \mathbf{v} - \mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k}. \end{align}We want this to equal $\mathbf{0},$ so \[\mathbf{v} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1/2 \\ 1/2 \\ 1/2 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "(crossproduct (vector [1,0,0]) (crossproduct (v - (vector [0,1,0])) (vector [1,0,0]))) + 
(crossproduct (vector [0,1,0]) (crossproduct (v - (vector [0,0,1])) (vector [0,1,0]))) + 
(crossproduct (vector [0,0,1]) (crossproduct (v - (vector [1,0,0])) (vector [0,0,1]))) = vector [0,0,0]"
shows  "v = vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a vector $v$ in three-dimensional space. If the sum of the cross products of the vector [1,0,0] with the cross product of the vector $v$ and the vector [1,0,0] minus the vector [0,1,0], the vector [0,1,0] with the cross product of the vector $v$ and the vector [0,1,0] minus the vector [0,0,1], and the vector [0,0,1] with the cross product of the vector $v$ and the vector [0,0,1] minus the vector [1,0,0], equals the zero vector [0,0,0], then find the vector $v$. The final answer is the vector [1/2, 1/2, 1/2].
